Description: Body sherd of Chian Grand Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior: glazed black with three bands in added white and red; exterior: glazed black save reserved band at centre with red lozenge pattern; above, painted decoration consisting of possible feline paws, to right; below, black zone with white band at bottom.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Price describes the feet as those of a bird but they seem more closely related to felines and sphinxes. For a parallel see Lemos 1991, no. 675 from Pitane. Lemos describes this sherd as in the light and dark technique. The vase was first slipped white, then black, followed by painted decoration using added red and added white. Whilst the technique is commonly found on the interior of Chian open vessels, it is not frequently found on the exterior surface of vases. Thus this sherd stands out as one of a small number of Grand Style vases created using the light and dark technique.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 119, p. 285, no. 811, pl. 114)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 82, no. 16, pl. V)
Price 1924 / Pottery of Naukratis (pl. IX, no. 6)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0840) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
